physDesc.p: This letter is five pages long. The word “Aldington” is written in pencil in the top left corner of the first page, slanting up from left to right at a 45 degree angle. There’s a faint embossing at the top of the paper that looks like “Berkshire Linen USA.” The date is listed on each page in the top right, and at the top left of each page after the first page is the annotation “R.A.–Page [#].”

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter of the 13th of June came a few days ago, and I was delighted to get it, and to know that you were really in camp. However awful it is to break up one’s life in this way, if it has to be done, I do think it is better to have it over, and not in anticipation.

I have ordered “The Poetry Review” went to you via Hilda. In it you will find a short and pleasant account of our Anthology by Professor Phelps of Yale. I am also sending you the May and June-July numbers of “The Little Review”. The latter contains an excellent criticism by Mrs. Aldis, and both of them contain an interesting paper on you and Hilda and Flint, by Fletcher. In the latter also is a poem of mine, which I like and which I hope you will like too, in spite of its being in polyphonic prose.
Don’t worry, I shall write to you constantly and tell you everything that is going on here. You certainly shall not drop out from anything that I can keep you up in.

I can certainly get your photograph into the “Transcript”, if you will send it on, and they will let me put a few lines under it, I am sure, in which I can give you a send-off. I wish you would send two – one for my own pleasure and one for the paper.

There is a new magazine being got up here. James Oppenheim is the editor and Louis Untermeyer and Robert Frost are two of the associate editors. It is to be called “The Seven Arts”, and is endowed at $25,000.00 a year for one year. The donor, whose name I do not know, is to let them run it as they please for a year, and if at the end of the time he is not satisfied with the result, he can withdraw his support; in which case they will try to raise the money on their year’s work. If, however, he is satisfied, as they hope he will be, the endowment will continue. They wish to print things relating to all the arts, and they pay on acceptance. They have no propaganda whatever, and are to be the spokesmen of no school. It sounds well; and although I do not suppose they will follow entirely the lines which we should like, nevertheless it seems to me hopeful. And I hope that whatever you may send me I shall now be able to place more advantageously than hitherto – with “The Poetry Review” and this new magazine as places to put things into.

Braithwaite is considering your poems, and he will certainly take some of them, if not all. What he does not take I shall send to Harriet Monroe. Braithwaite does not pay as well as Harriet, as you know. In fact, he pays painfully little, as his backer has only $2,000.00 a year to put into the magazine. But the advantage is that he prints his things at once, and he already has a much larger circulation than Harriet. Their news stand sale last month was three thousand copies. This is exclusive of subscriptions. I have also sent him your essays, and I think he will certainly take one of them. What he does not take I shall try to get printed elsewhere.

Our half-yearly account for the Anthology comes in on the first of August, and I sincerely trust that I shall have some money to send you then. I sent Hilda a draft for ten dollars, which I got out of Brown as the second payment on his agreement with me. He still owes you ten dollars on that agreement. But as I have succeeded in getting two payments, I have no doubt that I shall get the third in time, but probably not before Autumn. The poor devil is awfully stuck himself, and has just married, into the bargain. But I shall try for the last payment as soon as I return to town in the Autumn.

If you ever see “Others”, you will be surprised to find a poem in the current number by me. I say you will be surprised, because I told you that Fletcher and I had agreed not to go into it. This particular number is edited by William Carlos Williams, and he wrote and begged me to send something for his sake. I like Williams, but I told him that Fletcher and I had agreed to send nothing without consulting each other, and that, therefore, I could not send him anything. He replied that Fletcher had sent him a poem from England for this number. I don’t know why Fletcher did not let me know before he went back on our agreement, but in the letter I had from him, written two days before yours, he made no mention of this transaction. However, partly because Fletcher had sent a poem, partly because I like Williams, partly because I think the magazine has not been so objectionable lately, I did send him a poem; which fact I now greatly regret as I do not think this number at all good. It contains contributions from my particular detestations – Jeanne D’Orge and Mina Loy. Ezra has some more Chinese translations in it, and I think they are wretched. Fletcher’s poem, too, is not good.

Fletcher does not seem to have seen any of you since he has been in England. I think he is much taken up in being married at present. He sent me two poems the other day and asked me to sell them to “The Century” for him. I do not think them good, but he is so sensitive, I do not like to tell him that across the water. So I immediately sent them along. I do not know whether they will take them or not.

What you say about Hilda’s people hearing of our work in the West is very gratifying. There is a woman named Katherine Howard who is acting the part of John the Baptist for us, going from city to city in the Pacific Coast lecturing on our work for love, as she charges nothing for her lectures. She writes me that she has prepared the ground for me and that I must soon come. I think I shall take the advice and go out next Spring.

My lectures are extremely successful and, I think, have done considerable for the cause of our work. I am speaking on “The New Poetry, With Special Reference to Imagism” in St. Louis on November 7th, and I am giving four lectures on “Modern American Poets” at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in January. These four lectures will also be repeated in Boston and Chicago, and possibly in New York and Philadelphia. I am to talk before an elocution school up here on “Poetry as a Spoken Art” next month. My four lectures on American poets have one drawback for me, in that they do not permit me to include you and Flint, for which I am extremely sorry; but it was unavoidable. I am, however, giving one lecture to the American Imagists, in which I deal exclusively with Hilda and Fletcher, and I shall run in remarks about you and Flint along with them.

Lawrence wrote me: “We are gaily ringing our last shilling.” Whether this means his or England’s, I was unable to discover. I begged Fletcher to find out if he was in want, but he has not done so yet. If you know, I wish you would let me know, as I should not like him to suffer, and possibly the funds for such purposes which I left in Hilda’s hands are already exhausted. I hope to have some money to send him when I hear from Houghton Mifflin next month.

My own book, “Men, Women and Ghosts”, has gone to press and will be out in October. I hear from Ferris Greenslet that Hilda is to be issued in this country as one of the Autumn set of the New Poetry series. That is good news, and I shall review the book for either Braithwaite or “The Seven Arts”. I forget whether I sent you my review of you and Flint in “The Poetry Review”; but at any rate, it will come with the back numbers on the subscription I have just given for you.
It is amusing to see, in this number of “Others”, that Conrad Aiken, that arch-plagiarist, is now trying to write a la (sic) Imagists, having gone through the stages of Masefield and Masters!

I am afraid you will not like my new book much, as it is all stories, and some are in the despised stanza form that you objected to so much in my last book. I am afraid I was born eclectic and must write in every way to satisfy my soul. Some of these, however, I think you will like; in fact, I know you will, because you have already liked them.

My “Sword Blades” has just gone into a second edition. It has taken it a devil of a time to do it, but they printed a huge edition the first time. However, the sales are increasing, and that is something.

Write me as often as you can. I miss your letters awfully when I do not get them. I wrote to Hilda a week or so ago, and I shall write again very soon, as she must be dreadfully lonely, and I think writing is the best way to help her just now. It does look as if the war would soon be over, and you can be quite sure that as soon as it is I shall cross the ocean to see you all.
